column1: Cecina (Italian pronunciation: [ˈtʃɛːtʃina]) is a comune (municipality) of  28
column2: 322 inhabitants in the Province of Livorno in the Italian region Tuscany
column3: located about 80 kilometres (50 mi) southwest of Florence and about 30 kilometres (19 mi) southeast of Livorno.

column1: The territory of Cecina borders the following municipalities: Bibbona
An archaeological park close to the town houses the remains of a Roman villa from the 1st century BC.
A settlement was founded here by the Roman consul Albinus Caecina
column2: who was a descendant of an ancient Etruscan family. After the fall of the Western Roman Empire
column3: the territory suffered a long period of decline
column4: which only came to an end when the Grand Duke Leopold II of Tuscany began to develop local agriculture.

column1: The modern town was founded in 1852
column2: but a part of the city was destroyed during World War II. From the 1960s onwards
column3: it has developed into a popular tourist resort.
